SAFETY

All of the improvements and mitigation measures identified in the process hazard analysis, which the City of Redding committed to accomplish have been completed or are in progress.  Any other measures identified by employees during workplace hazard surveys or as a result of audit activities will be thoroughly reviewed and considered for implementation.   Disposition of these recommendations can be found in the committed action tracking log.  Currently, an upgrade that will replace Schedule 80 PVC that has been in place since 1991, a new dry medial scrubber, and other changes are planned for 2021.

The City of Redding is dedicated to inherently safer technology.  It is currently evaluating changing from chlorine and sulfur dioxide to ultraviolet light as its means of disinfection.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAMS

General accidental release prevention programs instituted by the City of Redding are categorized as administrative (management) programs; procedures, training, and engineering controls; PPE; and emergency response programs. The City of Redding, Wastewater Utilities, has instituted a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program meeting OSHA requirements at 29 CFR 1910.119, covering its disinfection and dechlorination process.  This constitutes the general accidental release prevention program for the City of Redding's operations.  The program and document management procedures included in the PSM Program are used as the management system for the Risk Management Program.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC RELEASE PREVENTION STEPS

Release prevention steps specific to chlorine and sulfur dioxide have been identified and implemented.  This includes, among other things, changing the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems with pressure gas piping and vacuum regulators mounted to the walls to a vacuum system where the vacuum regulators are directly mounted to the ton containers, and the system to the injector only works under vacuum.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no reportable accidents involving chlorine or sulfur dioxide at this facility within the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The City of Redding's Emergency Response Program applicable to chlorine and sulfur dioxide has been coordinated with Redding Hazmat. The City of Redding, Utilities Department, maintains First Responder capability with respect to chlorine and sulfur dioxide releases at its facilities.

stored in separate rooms inside an enclosed building that is dedicated to chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  The chlorine is used for odor control of the influent wastewater, to disinfect the wastewater effluent, and for other process uses.  The sulfur dioxide is used to dechlorinate the disinfected effluent for aquatic toxicity control.  Pressurized gas within each ton container is reduced to vacuum using a vacuum regulator valve mounted directly onto the ton container's gas valve.  The gas, under vacuum from up to two one-ton containers, is connected to one of two manifolds where it is metered through rate valves and rotameters in chlorinators or sulfonators located in a separate room.  For chlorine, the gas is drawn into water solution by the passage of pressurized water through an injector inside the dedicated building.  In the case of sulfur dioxide, the gas under partial vacuum travels underground in PVC piping to the outfall building up to 1 mile away. It is injected into the water and then added to the outfall pipe shortly before the final effluent is discharged into the Sacramento River.

The City removed sulfur dioxide in 2023 due to a lack of chemical being available.  This RMP employs predictive filing for sulfur dioxide and would return tusing this chemical if it becomes available again.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

It is the policy of the City of Redding that the receipt, storage, and handling of chlorine and sulfur dioxide at its facility be done in a manner which meets regulatory requirements and minimizes the probability and severity of accidental releases of chlorine to the atmosphere, in order to protect the health and safety of its workers, the public, and the environment. The City of Redding has instituted a Risk Management Program for their wastewater treatment facility, Clear Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant, as required by Federal Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) Program regulations at 40 CFR Part 68 and its California equivalent 19 CCR 2735ff, administered by Shasta County EHD.  A Risk Management Program:
  - identifies the equipment, procedures, maintenance, inspection, and training associated with Regulated Substances (RS's) handled at this facility in excess of Federal threshold quantities; 
  - describes the structured assessment of hazards which was conducted to assess possible onsite effects on employees and offsite public and environmental receptors; 
  - provides the results of an offsite consequences analysis.  
It defines a prevention program, emergency response program, and mitigation measures to reduce the probability and magnitude of accidental releases of RS's; and establishes a schedule and responsibilities for implementing mitigation measures, including auditing the program.  This Risk Management Plan (RMP)is being filed as required by Federal regulations to report the elements of the current Risk Management Program and to describe further measures planned to mitigate or prevent accidental releases of RS's.  

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The City of Redding operates two wastewater treatment plants: Clear Creek and Stillwater.  Stillwater Wastewater Treatment Plant is located at 6475 Airport Rd, Anderson, CA, in Shasta County. It uses chlorine and sulfur dioxide for effluent disinfection and dechlorination prior to its release to the Sacramento River.  Both chemicals are stored and used onsite in quantities greater than the Federal threshold quantity limits.  Stillwater is located on the east bank of the Sacramento River, just north of the City of Anderson.  There are 9 full-time employees at this site.
